groupByUrlname.description: Discuss and learn all the things regarding Clojure, ClojureScript, and functional programming

node.title: Madison Clojure Meetup: February 9
node.description:
Cliff Rodgers will present, "Paredit: A short introduction to structural editing". Before joining Bendyworks, a web development shop in Madison, Wisconsin, Cliff Rodgers earned a PhD in Neuroscience from University of Wisconsin-Madison. His research focused primarily on mechanisms of pain and memory. He has previously presented at the Society for Neuroscience annual meeting, the Neuropharmacology Conference on GABAergic Signaling in Health and Disease, and the International Symposium on Memory and Awareness in Anesthesia. In his spare time, he enjoys biking around Madison and the surrounding environs.

Update: We'll have pizza and soda, and then afterwards, whoever is interested should join us for a pint at the Great Dane.

venue.name: Bendyworks
venue.address: 106 E Doty Street, Suite 200, Madison, WI, 53703

node.text: Sorry I missed it!
A helpful and well presented introduction to Paredit, as proven by the fact that the presentation led to immediate exploration and discussion of it afterwards.
I really enjoyed all the great conversations. Cliff's talk was really excellent as well.

node.title: Madison Clojure Meetup: March 8
node.description:
Peter Schuck will present a talk on CLJS.

Peter is a senior level developer at Bendyworks. He spent 2 years as a contractor in Iraq and recently went about improving an inefficiency in the ClojureScript hashmaps. For that, he got Kudos from Om-Next’s David Nolan and his change may be adopted into the Clojure Core. He’s been developing with Clojure for 3 years.

We'll have dinner available, and will head for a pint at the Great Dane afterwards. Hope to see you there!

venue.name: Bendyworks
venue.address: 106 E Doty Street, Suite 200, Madison, WI, 53703

node.text: I'm excited to hear Peter's Clojure talk in less than a week!

Here's the repository for the talk and demo I'm going to give tonight

https://github.com/spinningtopsofdoom/cljs-start

node.title: Clojure Meetup
node.description:
Peter Schuck will be giving a talk at ClojureWest in Seattle later this month, and will be presenting it to us this Tuesday.

A recent paper http://michael.steindorfer.name/publications/oopsla15.pdf

has made some great improvements to Clojure's Hash Maps which include

​- 2x performance gains for iteration

- 10x - 100x performance gains for equality checks

- Lowers memory overhead

- Removes a lot of incedential complexity

​I'll be going into the details of how this accomplished

As always, join us for dinner at Bendyworks and we'll head for a pint at the Great Dane afterwards.

venue.name: Bendyworks
venue.address: 106 E Doty Street, Suite 200, Madison, WI, 53703

node.title: Presentation by James Elliott: Afterglow, Live Coding for Light Shows
node.description:
We are excited and honored to have our dear friend James Elliott give a thrilling presentation. Join us for food and fun. Afterwards, we'll head to the Great Dane for a pint.

James Elliott is a software developer who grew up hopping between continents, and got hooked on computers as a teenager in Mexico in the ’80s, to the extent of writing his own word processor in 6502 assembly language so he could turn in high school papers with proper fonts and justification long before he could afford a Mac. He’s written a few books for O’Reilly, and is now delighted to be working in Clojure professionally, helping Singlewire build platforms for mass notification. Having settled in Madison since graduate school, he has recently rekindled a passion for electronic music by discovering the fun of mixing it for an energetic crowd as Deep Symmetry.

http://deepsymmetry.org (http://deepsymmetry.org/)

Afterglow, Live Coding for Light Shows

Imagine being able to turn algorithmic ideas into a dazzling lightscape engulfing you and your audience. That's Afterglow, a live-coding environment for light shows.

As a software developer who creates electronic music shows as an avocation, I wanted a way to express my wildest ideas live, in harmony with music being played. Clojure was the perfect medium for building my dream tool.

Afterglow has grown from a crazy notion to a hub connecting several vibrant efforts in new, interesting ways, and has been used for performances on multiple continents. It can run alone, or hosted in Cycling '74's Max, a visual environment for experimenting with music and video. Afterglow translates abstract ideas into the low-level messages that control lighting fixtures. With the help of pieces of the Overtone project it powers intuitive physical control surfaces like Ableton Push, and offers beat synchronization with DJ equipment. I couldn't have achieved this without the expressiveness, interactivity, and compatibility of the Clojure environment, connecting everything in a coherent and extensible way. Clojure is ideal for building systems that need to walk and chew gum at the same time, and Afterglow does a lot at once.

I'll explain how this open-source project came together, how a Clojure functional mindset can produce streams of dazzling effects under an operator's tactile control, will demonstrate some effects with a few lights, and will provide an introduction to the architecture and implementation of the system. The demo and explanation can go in whatever directions the audience finds most interesting.

venue.name: Bendyworks
venue.address: 106 E Doty Street, Suite 200, Madison, WI, 53703

node.text: I’m wrapping up my plans for the demonstration, and it’s going to be a lot of fun to present and explain!
This is going to be such a great demonstration!!!

Thanks for coming, everyone! Chris an I swung by the Dane as soon as we got our gear safely loaded out, around twenty to nine, but it looked like we missed the drinking group. I look forward to chatting with everyone next time!

By the way, thanks for laughing at the Dysentery project name—Americans get that; Europeans, not so much! Definitely a forced pun on exploring Pioneer’s protocols, and I even linked to an image from The Oregon Trail at the bottom of the project page. ^_^ https://github.com/brunchboy/dysentery
Great presentation! Really impressed by how mature this project is...interface all the things!
Amazing pesentation! So much hard work has gone into the open source projects James demo'd. Extremely cool!
James did a great job keeping folks interested. He was enthusiastic, well-prepared and interjected the occasional humor to please the crowd! Fantastic presenter.
Very impressive software and excellent presentation! Obviously a bit of work to prepare for as well, so many thanks for taking the time!

Thanks again, everyone, and to Bendyworks for hosting this. I’ve finally finished captioning the video; if you want to see or share it, you can find it here: https://youtu.be/mvNN0SMMZDQ

Later that week I heard great news from Ableton: They want to work with me to add support for their Link synchronization protocol to “my amazing projects.” Woo hoo!

And the following week I was contacted by an Austrian DJ who was in Ibiza and had rented some CDJs to continue experimenting with Beat Link Trigger while there, because he wanted to use it in a show this weekend. Whoa… :)

node.title: David Whittington will present Reagent and DataScript
node.description:
ClojureScript is gaining popularity for client side web development, but which of the many ways to build a ClojureScript application should you choose?

This talk will present one combination of libraries to consider — Reagent, a ClojureScript React wrapper; DataScript, an in memory Clojure/ClojureScript DB with a Datomic like interface; and Posh, a library for linking them together.

David Whittington will describe what each library does and present an application architecture for tying them together. He will compare this architecture to other alternatives (Om, Om.next, re-frame) and show how the ClojureScript community seems to be converging on some common patterns. Finally, he will describe some of the pros and cons of the architecture presented and suggest under what circumstance you might want to use it.

David Whittington is an independent software developer with a background in web application development, configuration management, and healthcare information technology. He was most recently employed as a Software Architect by Sentry Data Systems. While there, he led Sentry's transition from package based server provisioning to Chef, was responsible for test automation and performance improvements to Sentry's pharmacy claims processing system, and developed an ETL pipeline for a prototype data warehousing product. Following his time at Sentry, David transitioned to working in Clojure full time and is currently developing his Clojure skills by building two applications — Memocorder (http://memocorder.com/), a notes management system, and Zetawar (http://www.zetawar.com/) , an open source turn-based tactical strategy game.

venue.name: Bendyworks
venue.address: 106 E Doty Street, Suite 200, Madison, WI, 53703

node.text: Great presentation! Your explanation of differences between Reagent and Om were very informative.

Thanks for coming out everyone. I had a ton of fun putting this together and presenting it. As promised, here are the links I shared at the end to help get you started with Reagent, DataScript, and Posh:

Reagent:

- Intro - http://reagent-project.github.io/
- News (has examples of new features) - http://reagent-project.github.io/news/index.html
- Lein template - https://github.com/reagent-project/reagent-template

DataScript/Datomic:

- DataScript - 
https://github.com/tonsky/datascript
- Datomic Docs - http://docs.datomic.com/
- Simulant (example code base) - https://github.com/Datomic/simulant
- Codeq (slightly dated example code base) - https://github.com/Datomic/codeq

Posh:

- https://github.com/mpdairy/posh

Server side + high level view:

- Datalog all the way down - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aI0zVzzoK_E
- Datsys (WIP client/server framework) - https://github.com/metasoarous/datsync
- The Web After Tomorrow - http://tonsky.me/blog/the-web-after-tomorrow/
Great presentation!  Thank you!!!
Just the right level of detail for an event like this, clearly explained, and great answers to questions.

After the talk we'll discuss lighting talks for the next meetup.

node.title: The Evolution of Zetawar
node.description: Zetawar (http://www.zetawar.com/) is a turn based strategy game written in ClojureScript. In July, David Whittington gave an overview of its architecture. He will briefly review the content of that talk for those who missed it and then examine how Zetawar has evolved over the past 6 months. This will cover moving from simple callback event handlers to reified events dispatched via core.async, implementing a message based AI interface, and optimizing Reagent and DataScript. He will conclude by summarizing his future plans for Zetawar and describing how to write your own Zetawar AI.

Great talk by David! Fun seeing how such elegant code drives his game.

node.title: Learn Clojure: Installfest and Introduction
node.description:
We'll be installing Clojure and introducing people to the core concepts of the language.

Resources for installation:

• Clojure Site: https://clojure.org/guides/getting_started

• Clojure for the Brave and True: http://www.braveclojure.com/getting-started/

• Clojure from the ground up: https://aphyr.com/posts/311-clojure-from-the-ground-up-logistics

Once you can get a repl up and running you can head to ClojureBridge (http://clojurebridge.github.io/community-docs/index.html) for an introduction to Clojure Concepts

If you want some sample problems head over to 4clojure (http://www.4clojure.com/problems).

People are welcome to come in at anytime.

node.title: Intro to Clojure: Core Functions and Data Structues
node.description:
Last Month we got installed Clojure and a REPL up and running.

This month we'll be going over the core functions and data structures. The meetup have the following structure

Show and Tell

People can show the progress they have made since last month's installfest if they so desire.

Here's some ideas of what you can show

Solutions to 4clojure problems (http://www.4clojure.com/problems)

A solution to a Project Euler problem (https://projecteuler.net/archives)

A drawing using Quil (https://github.com/quil/quil). You can read the tutorial (https://github.com/ClojureBridge/workshop-projects/blob/master/drawing_project/outline/first-program.md) and cheatsheet (https://github.com/ClojureBridge/curriculum/blob/gh-pages/outline/cheatsheet-quil.md) to make a drawing from scratch or modify a working quil example (http://quil.info/examples).

Guidance

After the show and tell we'll go around the room and ask what people want guidance on for Clojure.

Demonstration

Peter Schuck will show how to use Clojure's Core Data Structures (lists, maps, sets, keywords) and functions to change modify and query them.

He'll then go over three simple same problems showing a solution in an Object Oriented / Imperative language then the solution in Clojure.

The problems will be

Scoring a Bowling Game

Project Euler Problem 22 (https://projecteuler.net/problem=22)

Ruby Quiz Problem 114 (Housie) (http://rubyquiz.com/quiz114.html)

Resources

Clojure from the Ground posts on the Core Data Types (https://aphyr.com/posts/302-clojure-from-the-ground-up-basic-types) and Sequences (https://aphyr.com/posts/304-clojure-from-the-ground-up-sequences)

The Do Things (http://www.braveclojure.com/do-things/) chapter from Clojure for the Brave and True

ClojureDocs (http://clojuredocs.org/) has detailed documentation on Clojure function and a Quick Reference (http://clojuredocs.org/quickref)

venue.name: Bendyworks
venue.address: 106 E Doty Street, Suite 200, Madison, WI, 53703

node.title: Clojure Extension Points: Protocols, Multimethods, and types
node.description:
Presentation - Peter Schuck

One of Clojure's core ideas is the Alan Perlis quote " It is better to have 100 functions operate on one data structure than 10 functions on 10 data structures. ". We go even further and say that it's better to have 100 functions that operate on one abstraction.

The sequence abstraction ( https://clojure.org/reference/sequences ) is the most well known. It works not only for all Clojure data structures but Java Collections and Java Strings.

This presentation will go through these extension points, Protocols, Multi Methods, and data types. It will show how to add on new abstractions for existing data types, create new data types that implement Clojure's abstractions, how to make a new abstraction extension point, and rules of thumb of when it's best to use the tools.

After the presentation we'll go through some exercises making our own protocols and data types.

References - Videos

Protocol XIII: Clojure Protocols Explained - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kQhOlWXXl2I

PurelyFunctional TV: What Problems do Clojure Protocols Solve? - https://purelyfunctional.tv/clojure-protocols/what-problems-do-clojure-protocols-solve/

References - Online Book

Clojure for the Brave and True: Chapter 13 - http://www.braveclojure.com/multimethods-records-protocols/

node.title: Datomic: The Immutable Database
node.description:
Global mutable state is the progenitor of a thousand difficult to find bugs. Nearly all applications keep global mutable state to a minimum. There is one huge hidden source of global mutable state: the database.

Datomic (http://www.datomic.com/) removes that last store of global mutable state, squashing a multitude of bugs. Testing also becomes much simpler once your database is immutable.

Peter Schuck will present how Datomic works, it's use and several of it's superpowers like:

• Unlimited read capabilities that don't block writes

• Automatic auditing capabilities to track who made what change when

• Building queries out of data structures instead of string concatenation

• Speculatively updating the database to see how adding data can change queries

• Navigating a database entity like an object removing most of the need for an ORM.

Sorry, I'm coming down with something and will sit this one out.
Good talk! Excellent presentation of Datomic's features.

node.title: Lumo: Clojure(Script) without the JVM
node.description:
Lumo: I heard you like ClojureScript...

...so, I put some ClojureScript in your ClojureScript, so you can eval while you execute... or, something like that.

This talk is about Lumo, a self-hosted ClojureScript environment with zero JVM dependence, lightning fast load time, and easy access to the Node.js ecosystem. If you've ever been frustrated by JVM startup time or wanted to write CLI scripts in Clojure(Script), this talk is for you. Come learn about how Lumo works, how to use it, and some potential use cases.

Informative and worth the trip!

node.title: Dependency Heaven with tools.deps
node.description:
• What we'll do
With the release of Clojure 1.9.0 came an official Clojure tool to help manage dependencies and Clojure Environemts "tools.deps"(https://clojure.org/guides/deps_and_cli). "tools.deps" does not handle any building of artifacts it instead focuses on dependency resolution and downloads. See how to use this new tool from the command line and how it makes spinning up a Clojureproject easy.

Schedule

6:30
Food and socialization. Help setting up a Clojure Development environmet

6:50
Presentation on "tools.deps"

7:20
Discussion of topic, format and time for next meetup

Some ideas for future meetups

Machine Learning
How to use tools like "flare"(https://github.com/aria42/flare) or "cortex"(https://github.com/thinktopic/cortex)

Functional Package Managers
Functional ideas applied to package management. Examples are NixOs(https://nixos.org/) and Guix (https://www.gnu.org/software/guix/)

Advanced Data Navigation with Specter
See how navigating and modifying immutable data becomes even easier in Clojure with Specter(https://github.com/nathanmarz/specter/)

7:40
Wrap up, socialization

• What to bring

• Important to know

node.title: Speccing with Confidence
node.description:
A case study in when, where, and how to use specs to make application development simpler and more resilient.

Dan Petranek will talk about using Clojure Spec to design a ClojureScript game and deal with multiple refactorings. There will be lots of opportunities for questions and discussion.

Schedule

6:45 - Presentation Starts

7:30 - Presentation Ends and Discussion of next meetup topic

7:45 - Cleanup

venue.name: Bendyworks
venue.address: 106 E Doty Street, Suite 200, Madison, WI, 53703

node.text: A great description of how Spec turned out in practical use, and an interesting project to learn about.

node.title: CRDTS: A safety net for walking the distributed system tightrope
node.description:
The world of distributed applications is a very strange place where the past can repeat itself, causality works according to the networks whims, and errors flicker into and out of existence leaving caused by the mysterious alignments of servers.

Programmers are frequenting this world more and more often driven by the pressures for speed and scalability. Even the common ecommerce websites have to deal with distributed system problems if more than two clients are ordering items at the same time.

Peter Schuck will show how Commutative Replicated Data Types (CRDT's) provide a safety net for developers. CRDT's allow developers to focus on the actual application and less on the distributed aspect of it. Even when CRDT's aren't used the ideas behind them are useful guidelines for building distributed applications.

Schedule

6:30 - Food and socialization
6:45 - Presentation Starts
7:20 - Presentation Ends Q & A time
7:35 - Discussion of next month's topic
7:45 - Cleanup

Resources

A CRDT Primer Part I: Defanging Order Theory:
http://jtfmumm.com/blog/2015/11/17/crdt-primer-1-defanging-order-theory/

Big(ger) Sets: Making CRDT Sets Scale in Riak by Russell Brown:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f20882ZSdkU

venue.name: Bendyworks
venue.address: 106 E Doty Street, Suite 200, Madison, WI, 53703

node.text: The presentation is up on github at https://github.com/spinningtopsofdoom/madison-clojure-meetup-crdts

node.title: Advent of Code, for Clojure experts and beginners
node.description:
It's December, and that can only mean one thing: Santa needs saving again, and your coding skills can help!

After a long hiatus, the Madison Clojure Meetup is back! We'll get together to get beginners up and running with the language and the REPL, then solve some Advent of Code puzzles. The 2019 Advent of Code puzzles will be available at the link below starting December 1st, but you can try out puzzles from past years if you want to get started early.

https://adventofcode.com/2019
https://adventofcode.com/2018
https://adventofcode.com/2017

For newcomers to Clojure we'll have environment setup and language introduction resources available, as well as experienced Clojure users on hand to guide you through getting started. Feel free to run through some of the resources linked below prior to the meetup if you want a head start.

Experienced Clojure users can come ready to crank out solutions to a few Advent of Code puzzles. Stay until the end when folks can share their solutions and show off any interesting Clojure features employed.

Bendyworks are generously providing food and drink for the event.

# Environment Setup:

Java & Leiningen & Atom editor setup: https://gist.github.com/bgrabow/09511315debc40918fe4b7337c139c8f

# Learn Clojure:

If you're short on time: Learn Clojure in Y Minutes
https://learnxinyminutes.com/docs/clojure/

A more comprehensive intro: Clojure for the Brave and True
http://www.braveclojure.com/getting-started/

node.text: I've put the code I'm going to use for Parsing with Clojure Spec here https://github.com/spinningtopsofdoom/parsing-with-clojure-spec. See everyone tomorrow!
A good idea, Peter. Here is a link to the code I'll be using tonight: https://github.com/eatobin/meetup-madison.git. See you then...
It's kind of annoying how, when you type a URL followed by a period in a Meetup comment field, the link it generates includes the period.
Thanks everyone for the presentations and questions! Dan and I will be doing research into Datahike (https://github.com/replikativ/datahike/) for the next meetup presentation

node.title: A Datahike Game of Life
node.description:
Conway's Game of Life has been souped up with datahike (https://github.com/replikativ/datahike) an open source immutable database. Using Datahike you can easily time travel between previous steps, split off game into their own universe and perform queries comparing games across time and space.

Peter Schuck will present on how Datahike enabled all the above features and the use Clojure REPL tooling like Reveal (https://vlaaad.github.io/reveal/) to help speed up development and debugging.

Follow along with the development at https://github.com/spinningtopsofdoom/immutable_life

node.title: Advent of Clojure
node.description:
We'll be going over solutions to Advent of Code (https://adventofcode.com/) problems

Advent of Code is site that gives two problems to solve each day of December. The problems start out easy and get harder and more complicated with each passing day. We'll be presenting our solutions to the problems and going over the techniques we used.

node.title: Advent Of Code Clojure Challenges
node.description:
Well be solving the Advent of Code Day 1 Challenges (https://adventofcode.com/2021/day/1) using Clojure to demonstrate different ways of problem solving using Clojure

For extra credit you can try solving the Advent of Code Day 2 Challenges (https://adventofcode.com/2021/day/2)

node.text: Sadly I can't make this one. I'll be on a family trip.
I'm also going to be out of town that week. Have a good time!

node.title: Scripting Clojure with Babashka
node.description:
Tired of looking up Bash syntax? Lost your train of thought a few too many times waiting for Clojure to startup? Then this is the presentation for you!

Come find out how Babashka (https://github.com/babashka/babashka) can make your life easier by replacing complex shell scripts and providing a quick-to-start Clojure REPL. We'll cover the basics of how to setup Babashka and explore a few ways you might use it. Also, if we have time, we'll explore some related tools in the "Borkverse"

node.text: A bit overdue on this, but here are my slides: https://github.com/djwhitt/presentations/blob/main/docs/2022-11-29-scripting-clojure-with-babashka.md
Also, Happy New Year!

node.title: Clojure Performance Discussion
node.description:
We'll be discussing Clojure(Script) performance at Central Library Study Room 201. Specific topics will include how to measure Clojure performance, the programming patterns for writing performant code in the Clojure host (the JVM or JavaScript), and how to speed up Clojure Code

Some great videos talking about Clojure Performace

1. [Playing Go with Clojure](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v5dYE0CMmHQ) (2012) Zach Tellman describes what is needed to make a Clojure AI that can play Go
2. [LMAX Disruptor](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DCdGlxBbKU4) (2011) Trisha Gee & Mike Barker talk about the disruptor for messaging at LMAX. A deep dive is done on concurrency topics like cache coherency and memory barriers
3. [Designing for Performance](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=03GsLxVdVzU) (2016) Martin Thompson talks about a diverse range of topics like Queueing Theory and the Universal Scalability Law and how they apply to designing high speed systems
4. [Breaking the JavaScript Speed Limit with V8](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UJPdhx5zTaw) (2012) Daniel Clifford goes through the internals of the V8 JavaScript engine showing what code the V8 engine can easily optimize for
5. [John Carmack Tech Talk with UMKC-SCE](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lHLpKzUxjGk) (2017) John Carmack discusses getting a smooth VR experience from the hardware level

Food and Drinks will be provided by [Bendyworks](https://bendyworks.com/)

venue.name: Madison Public Library - Central
venue.address: 201 W Mifflin St

node.text: Out of town - or I'd be there...
The room is Study Room 201

node.title: Fluree: an Immutable, Verifiable, Shareable Database
node.description:
Come learn about bringing immutable data to the world of system design! We'll talk about why and how you can use Fluree, an immutable graph database, to make reliable systems. Dan Petranek will be presenting on the Fluree Database

Food and drinks will be provided. Notes from the meetup will be written up and then posted online

Before the presentation start we'll spend about 10 to 15 minutes about what we want the next meetup topic to be about. Some example ideas
\* Clojure REPL tooling showcase
\* Using Clojure with Large Language Models
\* Developing with Flutter using Clojure Dart

venue.name: Madison Public Library - Central
venue.address: 201 W Mifflin St

node.title: Bring your own REPL (BYOR)
node.description:
Show your REPL tooling and learn new techniques from other Clojure Developers. The REPL (Read Eval Print Loop) is one of Clojure's great strengths that is constantly being added onto with new tools like the [Flow Storm Debugger](https://github.com/jpmonettas/flow-storm-debugger). If you're a newcomer to Clojure stop on by to learn about all the ways you can enhance your Clojure REPL experience.

Food and drinks will be provided. Notes from the meetup will be written up and then posted online

Before the presentation start we'll spend about 10 to 15 minutes about what we want the next meetup topic to be about.

venue.name: Madison Public Library - Central
venue.address: 201 W Mifflin St

node.text: Something came up and I am unable to make it tonight. I really wanted to attend. Maybe next time.

Whelp, sorry I forgot my bike lock and had to head back. Ironic since I reminded some others about this one. If anyone wants to see Conjure + Neovim, Malli + LSP, Portal (guessing this one is already being shown), or Mount REPL integration at some future meetup, let me know.

node.title: Clojure Game of Life: A Project's Journey
node.description:
Show how to build a small Clojure Project (the Game of Life). Head over to [https://github.com/spinningtopsofdoom/madison-clojure-example-project](https://github.com/spinningtopsofdoom/madison-clojure-example-project) read the README for instructions and then start building the Game of Life. We'll all share how the Clojure project creation process went and the way we went about building the project.

Several examples of Clojure Game of life projects can be found at [github](https://github.com/search?q=game+of+life+language%3AClojure&type=repositories). The Game of Life does not need to be 100% completed or polished to a fine sheen. We're here to show all the different ways to start a Clojure Project and learn from each other.

Snacks and Drinks will be provided. We'll be posting the [notes](https://github.com/spinningtopsofdoom/madison-clojure-example-project/blob/main/notes/01-Life-Creation.md) from the meetup to help other begin their Clojure Journey

node.title: HYBRID: Leveling Up Clojure Runtime Specs
node.description:
Clojure has a powerful selection of dynamic verification tools, including Schema, Spec, and Malli. In this talk, we will motivate the need for even more expressive runtime specifications. Repurposing familiar ideas from static types and interpreters, we will explore higher-level abstractions over runtime specs that bump up their expressivity without compromising their dynamism.

The talk will also be [streamed live](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2vAyJPwogSI) with a VOD later.

Agenda:

* 6:30pm arrive and eat (was thinking pizza), please record any dietary restrictions [here](https://forms.gle/AbzGfXPDT9AXkqAs9).
* start stream, 7pm talk
* 7:45pm all questions
* 8pm end stream, offline questions
* 8:30pm end meetup, people who want to hang out can choose from nearby bars and restaurants

speakerDetails.name: Ambrose Bonnaire-Sergeant
speakerDetails.description: Ambrose has been an active member of the Clojure community since 2011. He has participated in the development of many dynamic verification tools for Clojure, including trammel, core.contracts, dynalint, Schema, Spec, test.chuck, typed.clj.spec and Malli. He is the creator of Typed Clojure, the subject of his PhD thesis, and a maintainer of Plumatic Schema.

node.text: Thanks for giving such an interesting talk, Ambrose, and thank you to everyone who was able to attend! I very much enjoyed the conversations both before and after. And the gift of pizza! We should schedule meetups to just chat even when we don’t have people ready to present something, I love getting to know our great community better.
VOD https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QE3PZLlefUE

node.title: HYBRID: Immutable Databases to Set Your Distributed System Free
node.description:
Writing software is just great until you need to get two different machines to agree on some state. Then you have to start solving some difficult problems. In Clojure we can see how immutable data makes building concurrent programs manageable -- what if we could apply those same lessons to our distributed systems? We'll talk about what an immutable database is, how it works in principle and in practice, and why you'll want to use one to make your life easier.

The talk will also be streamed live and a VOD will be posted later: [https://youtube.com/live/zx4HGVx9NR8](https://youtube.com/live/zx4HGVx9NR8)

Agenda:

* 6:30pm arrive, pizza served

* 7:45pm all questions
* 8:00pm end stream, offline questions
* 8:30pm end meetup, people who want to hang out can choose from nearby bars and restaurants

speakerDetails.description: Daniel has been writing Clojure since 2013. He likes immutable data, conflict-free replicated data types, and aperiodic tilings. He is currently a maintainer of the free and open source immutable graph database, Fluree.

node.title: HYBRID: Clojure Virtual Threads, CSS Accessibility, and Theory of Constraints
node.description:
We have three talks this month!

Agenda:
\- 6:30pm arrive and eat \(pizza\)
\- 7:00pm talks \(3 x 15\+5m\)
\- 8:00pm official business ends\, stay for informal discussion and food

[Live Stream](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uIfynMppxcw)

**Talk 1: [Eric Normand](ericnormand.me)**

**Virtual Threads in Clojure**
JDK 21 provides virtual threads which allow for much more concurrency than OS threads. In this talk, we'll see how to use them from Clojure, how they differ from OS threads, and what might change in the future.

**Bio**
Eric Normand is a Clojure and functional programming teacher. He has been programming in Clojure since 2008 and teaching it since 2013. You can find him online at [ericnormand.me](http://ericnormand.me/).

**Talk 2: [Sayan Sivakumaran](https://sayansivakumaran.com/)**

**How does CSS affect the Accessibility Tree?**
It's a common misconception that HTML is the only thing that affects how assistive technologies (like screen readers) interact with the web, even though that isn't true. For example, did you know that [the CSS border styling of table cells](https://sayansivakumaran.com/posts/2023/6/browser-table-accessibility-remediation/#determining-table-ness-via-the-css-border-of-table-cells) affects whether small HTML tables are exposed as a table in the accessibility tree or not? Other types of CSS can change how the accessibility tree is exposed as well - there has been an attempt to standardize this behavior with [the CSS-AAM](https://w3c.github.io/css-aam/), although there doesn't seem to have been a lot of work in this area recently.

Let's explore some of the weird, implementation-defined ways that CSS can affect the accessibility tree!

**Bio**
[Sayan Sivakumaran](https://sayansivakumaran.com/) is a developer at Singlewire that has done open source work on both Chromium accessibility and the ARIA specification suite (more specifically, the Core-AAM). While they are taking a temporary break from open source accessibility work to explore systems programming, making the web more accessible is still something that they hold close to their heart!

**Talk 3: David Whittington**

**Exploring Clojure as a Theory of Constraints modeling environment**
The "Theory of Constraints" (TOC) is a management philosophy introduced by Dr. Eliyahu M. Goldratt in his 1984 book titled "The Goal". It is designed to help organizations continually achieve their goals by identifying and managing constraints that hinder performance. The central premise of TOC is that every system, regardless of how well it performs, has at least one constraint that limits its ability to achieve more of its goals.

Various software software tools exist to support the TOC modeling process, but they're generally not hacker friendly. Can we do better in Clojure? Let's tinker and find out.

**Bio**
David Whittington is a system architect at PDS, Inc. where he is helping build [ar.io](http://ar.io/), an access protocol for the Arweave perpetual data storage network. Previously he has worked on streaming metrics indexing and simulation testing for satellite systems, a ClojureScript strategy game (Zetawar), pharmacy claims processing systems, and early IaaC systems. He enjoys free software, permissionless systems, functional programming, optimizing databases, and immutability.

node.title: Beat Link Trigger: Clojure for DJ shows
node.description:
You might have seen James’ [Afterglow demo](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mvNN0SMMZDQ) at the [Meetup in 2016](https://www.meetup.com/Madison-Clojure-Meetup/events/229842513/), now you can see what has devoured his spare time since then. At that meetup James mentioned he’d started to reverse-engineer the protocol used by Pioneer DJ pro gear so he could sync light shows to it. That spawned its own set of projects which have blown up, and he’s been contacted by several artists who feature prominently in his own music collection for help using the software in their tours and streams, and even tricked Deadmau5 into learning a little Clojure.

This presentation will explore how DJ performances work today, give highlights of the degree to which we can now tap into the hardware over the network, and demonstrate some of the cool tricks this enables. Clojure has been the glue that allowed James to accidentally create an integration environment for performances, in response to interesting ideas from club resident techs, touring performers, and their front-of-house tech crews.

venue.name: Singlewire Software
venue.address: 1002 Deming Way

speakerDetails.name: James Elliott
speakerDetails.description: James is a software developer who grew up hopping between continents, and got hooked on computers as a teenager in Mexico in the ’80s, to the extent of writing his own word processor in 6502 assembly language so he could turn in high school papers with proper fonts and justification long before he could afford a Mac. He’s written a few books for O’Reilly, and is now delighted to be working in Clojure professionally, helping Singlewire build platforms for mass notification. Having settled in Madison since graduate school, he has recently rekindled a passion for electronic music by discovering the fun of mixing it for an energetic crowd as [Deep Symmetry](https://deepsymmetry.org/) and connecting with people around the world looking for new ways to integrate their shows.

node.title: Immutable Web of Values (Downtown @ StartingBlock)
node.description:
This month we will help David develop a talk he's proposing for Clojure/conj 2024. It will not be live streamed but we will record the practice talk to be submitted along with the proposal.

Location is **downtown** at StartingBlock.

Agenda:
\- 6:30pm arrive and eat \(pizza\)
\- 7:00pm talk
\- 8:00pm official business ends\, stay for informal discussion and food

**Speaker**: David Whittington

**Talk**: Immutable Web of Values

**Description:**

Do you like immutable values? Do you ever wish the web was made out of persistent data structures? There are real projects underway to make this happen.
Come to this talk to learn about the various efforts to construct large-scale decentralized storage systems, so we can finally have an immutable web of values. We'll cover things like IPFS, IPLD, Arweave, Filecoin, and other related technologies.
Warning: this talk will mention blockchains! If this is off-putting, do not fear! There will be plenty of non-blockchain content, and blockchains will be discussed purely as an implementation strategy to solve particular technical problems.

**Bio**
David Whittington is a system architect at PDS, Inc. where he is helping build [ar.io](http://ar.io/), an access protocol for the Arweave perpetual data storage network. Previously he has worked on streaming metrics indexing and simulation testing for satellite systems, a ClojureScript strategy game (Zetawar), pharmacy claims processing systems, and early IaaC systems. He enjoys free software, permissionless systems, functional programming, optimizing databases, and immutability.

venue.name: StartingBlock Madison
venue.address: 821 E Washington Ave 2nd floor

node.title: Reconsidering Malli Scope
node.description:

Talk:
[Malli](https://github.com/metosin/malli) is a popular runtime verification library for Clojure. In this talk we will review how Malli approaches scope via registries and refs then motivate alternative (backwards-compatible) designs.

node.title: Constraining Malli Schemas, by Ambrose Bonnaire-Sergeant
node.description:
\>\>\>\> [STREAM](https://www.youtube.com/live/28S96Ms8WOc) <<<<

This event is not at our usual time in order for the stream to be accessible from a cross-section of time-zones.

A video will be posted after the event.

Food will be provided. Please RSVP so we can prepare.

For in-person attendees, please remember [Eric's practice talk next month](https://www.meetup.com/madison-clojure-meetup/events/301041832/?eventOrigin=group_upcoming_events).

Agenda:

* 11:30am feel free to arrive, use the stairs in the lobby to get to the 2nd floor at our usual room.
* 12pm talk and stream starts
* 12:45pm talk ends, online questions.
* 1pm end stream, offline questions
* 2pm end meetup

Talk Title: Constraining Malli Schemas

Talk Abstract:
In this talk we look at some ways Malli schemas are not expressive enough and must resort to partial workarounds. For example, to specify a map with one key or another but not both, the dreaded addition of :and + :fn is needed to assert a postcondition on the map. This then negatively affects error messages and generating examples.

We then propose a clean solution to this problem, and many problems like it, by adding support for constraints on individual schemas.

node.title: Clojure Conference Takeaways and Inspirations
node.description:
**Announcement**: We might be moving off Meetup.com in December 2024. Our permanent website is [madclj.com](https://madclj.com) which has a [Web Calendar](https://madclj.com/calendar/) you can also [subscribe to](https://madclj.com/events.ics). RSVP will be via GitHub Discussions for now ([this event](https://github.com/orgs/madclj/discussions/6)).

The Clojure community held two large conferences over the last two months. Several of our regulars attended and/or spoke, and last meetup we phoned in to catch the last day of Clojure/conj.

A lot happened at these conferences. This meetup will provide space to discuss our experience, takeaways and inspirations.

Topics:
\- hallway track reports
\- favorite talks
\- conference followups \(new projects/collaborations\, ideas\, initiatives\)
\- industry and community trends

No online stream is planned.

Agenda:
\- 6:30pm arrive\, food & drink provided \(pizza\, bottled water\, sparkling water\, candy\, fruit\)
\- 7pm start structured discussion
\- 8pm end structured discussion
\- 9pm end meetup

node.title: Celebrating A Year of (Madison) Clojure
node.description:
**Announcement**: We might be moving off Meetup.com in December 2024. Our permanent website is [madclj.com](https://madclj.com) which has a [Web Calendar](https://madclj.com/calendar/) you can also [subscribe to](https://madclj.com/events.ics). RSVP will be via GitHub Discussions for now ([this event](https://github.com/orgs/madclj/discussions/7)).

It's been a busy year! This will be our 11th and final meetup of 2024.

Let's wind down and celebrate the year together. We'll have a loosely structured discussion about our year with an eye towards Madison Clojure in 2025.

Topics:
\- what characterized Clojure in 2024 for you?
\- feedback on Madison Clojure in 2024
\- planning 2025

Whether this is streamed will be determined closer to the event.

Agenda:
\- 6:30pm arrive\, food & drink provided \(TBD\)
\- 7pm start structured discussion
\- 8pm end structured discussion
\- 9pm end meetup

node.text: We should also, probably ahead of this, see if anyone wants to pick up the Meetup Pro sponsorship fees for the next year. My renewal payment of $180 for the next six months is coming due December 6th, and I don’t plan to give them the updated credit card information they need even if I am unable to navigate their dark patterns of canceling it by contacting their billing department. Can we find a less overpriced way to organize and keep in touch with people?
